There are 2 aspects of security: cost of miner machines protecting the network AND electricity cost to run the machines. Being scrypt dominant means that there’s no easy way to get enough machines to attack, so pretty secure. But total cost of all miners about 1/10 of Bitcoin.

Since Litecoin blocks are 4 times faster than Bitcoin’s, the network can handle a sudden decrease in hashrate much better. If 75% of hashrate disappears overnight, Litecoin just acts like Bitcoin for 2 wks (10 mins blks) and then diff retargets and everything is back to normal.

6/ But the code that was released was mostly written in 2018. The interesting thing about GitHub is that it keeps the commit the same in terms of who wrote it and when it was committed to the code base. So Bitcoin developers are credited for their work in the Litecoin code base.

5/ First reason is Litecoin releases lag Bitcoin releases by a few months. So when we do a release, we are releasing code that's been released in Bitcoin months ago. We actually did release Litecoin Core 0.17.1 May of this year:

2/ It's no secret that we have purposefully kept Litecoin's code very close to Bitcoin's code. Since we are mostly just merging in Bitcoin changes, we only need a lead Litecoin Core developer doing the merges and the rest of us help with code reviews, testing, and gitian builds.

So, for small disputes the chain or smart contract would likely handle it. This happens many times per day with Bitcoin & Ethereum. For larger disputes you might need to go outside to a legal system. Note this is separate from legal requirements which will vary by jurisdiction.
You’re again stuck on bitcoin L1. As with USD, there are many protocols for transferring a financial asset, optimized for different things.

You keep conflating Bitcoin the settlement layer for bitcoin the financial asset. As with USD, scaleability can be achieved via higher layers. A limitation of L1 bitcoin is not a limitation for bitcoins. Weird that you keep arguing otherwise. We have many protocols for USD.

Price volatility is separate from other features and a function of a currency’s stage of adoption. Bitcoin is of course a new hypervolatile speculative asset. If it succeeds, it’s vol will gradually fall, as the USD did in the 1800s for example.

Sigh. You keep harping on the same “bitcoin is a bad competitor to visa” when its competing with the offshore banking system. And you keep ignoring the future introduction of higher layers. Venmo is the wrong comparison, the equivalent doesn’t even exist yet on top of bitcoin.

I thought we already covered usage? More people use bitcoin than used the internet or credit cards at a comparable stage of development (10 years after introduction.) it never had a chance at L1 being a leading payment rail, good riddance we have plenty of ways to buy coffee.
